solution_line_template: If there are {sharks_pelican_bay} sharks in Pelican Bay, and this number is twice the number of Pelicans that usually live in Shark Bite Cove, then there were {sharks_pelican_bay}/{sharks_multiple_of_pelicans}=<<{sharks_pelican_bay}/{sharks_multiple_of_pelicans}={initial_pelicans_shark_bite_cove}>>{initial_pelicans_shark_bite_cove} Pelicans in Shark Bite Cove.

then {initial_pelicans_shark_bite_cove}/{fraction_moved_denominator}=<<{initial_pelicans_shark_bite_cove}/{fraction_moved_denominator}={pelicans_moved_away}>>{pelicans_moved_away} Pelicans will have moved away.

This would leave {initial_pelicans_shark_bite_cove}-{pelicans_moved_away}=<<{initial_pelicans_shark_bite_cove}-{pelicans_moved_away}={remaining_pelicans_shark_bite_cove}>>{remaining_pelicans_shark_bite_cove} Pelican remaining in Shark Bite Cove.
